body_html:
@haraldschilly the latest tensorboard source uses all relative URLs. You can use a proxy with tensorboard if you remove the base path before proxying.

example:

Let's say you have a proxy located at www.server.example, you have a path defined for Tensorboard like so: http://www.server.example/base/path/ , and your Tensorboard server is listening at 192.0.0.20:6006

You want to make sure your proxy forwards http://www.server.example/base/path/ to http://192.0.0.20:6006/. When your client (firefox, chrome, etc) calls the URL, http://www.server.example/base/path/, you need to make sure you have a / on the end of the path, or else the relative URLs will chop off the last bit of the path.

You want to make sure your proxy forwards http://www.server.example/base/path/ to http://192.0.0.20:6006/. When your client (firefox, chrome, etc) calls the URL, http://www.server.example/base/path/, you need to make sure you have a / on the end of the path, or else the relative URLs will chop off the last bit of the path.
body:
@haraldschilly the latest tensorboard source uses all relative URLs. You can use a proxy with tensorboard if you remove the base path before proxying.

example:

Let's say you have a proxy located at `www.server.example`, you have a path defined for Tensorboard like so: `http://www.server.example/base/path/` , and your Tensorboard server is listening at `192.0.0.20:6006`

You want to make sure your proxy forwards `http://www.server.example/base/path/` to `http://192.0.0.20:6006/`. When your client (firefox, chrome, etc) calls the URL, `http://www.server.example/base/path/`, you need to make sure you have a `/` on the end of the path, or else the relative URLs will chop off the last bit of the path.
